title: Famous Scientists Recall
description: Can you recall the brilliant scientists who changed our understanding of the world?

questions.question: Which scientist developed the theory of general relativity?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein published his theory of general relativity in 1915, revolutionizing our understanding of gravity, space, and time.

questions.question: Who discovered penicillin, the first widely used antibiotic?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928 when he noticed that a mold (Penicillium) killed bacteria in his lab. He won the Nobel Prize in 1945.

questions.question: Which scientist is known for his laws of motion and universal gravitation?
questions.explanation: Sir Isaac Newton published his laws of motion and universal gravitation in 'Principia Mathematica' in 1687.

questions.question: Who proposed the theory of evolution by natural selection?
questions.explanation: Charles Darwin published 'On the Origin of Species' in 1859, presenting his theory of evolution by natural selection.

questions.question: Which scientist won two Nobel Prizes, one in Physics and one in Chemistry?
questions.explanation: Marie Curie won the Nobel Prize in Physics (1903) for her research on radiation and in Chemistry (1911) for discovering radium and polonium.

questions.question: Who developed the first successful polio vaccine?
questions.explanation: Jonas Salk developed the first successful inactivated polio vaccine, announced in 1955. He chose not to patent it to ensure wider distribution.

questions.question: Which scientist's X-ray crystallography work was crucial to discovering DNA's structure?
questions.explanation: Rosalind Franklin's X-ray crystallography image (Photo 51) was key to Watson and Crick's discovery of DNA's double helix structure in 1953.

questions.question: Who is known as the father of modern astronomy for his use of the telescope?
questions.explanation: Galileo Galilei improved the telescope and made groundbreaking astronomical observations including Jupiter's moons and the phases of Venus.

questions.question: Which scientist developed the periodic table of elements?
questions.explanation: Dmitri Mendeleev published his periodic table in 1869, organizing elements by atomic weight and predicting the existence of undiscovered elements.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'father of genetics' for his work with pea plants?
questions.explanation: Gregor Mendel's experiments with pea plants in the 1860s established the fundamental laws of inheritance, though his work wasn't recognized until decades later.

questions.question: Which scientist invented the light bulb and held over 1,000 patents?
questions.explanation: Thomas Edison developed the first practical incandescent light bulb in 1879 and held 1,093 US patents during his prolific career.

questions.question: Who proposed the heliocentric model of the solar system in the 16th century?
questions.explanation: Nicolaus Copernicus proposed that the Earth and other planets revolve around the Sun, publishing his theory in 1543.

questions.question: Which physicist is known for his uncertainty principle in quantum mechanics?
questions.explanation: Werner Heisenberg formulated the uncertainty principle in 1927, stating that the position and momentum of a particle cannot both be precisely known simultaneously.

questions.question: Who invented the telephone in 1876?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell patented the telephone on March 7, 1876, and made the first successful telephone call to his assistant Thomas Watson.

questions.question: Which scientist developed the theory of radioactivity and coined the term?
questions.explanation: Marie Curie coined the term 'radioactivity' and developed the theory through her extensive research on radioactive elements, particularly radium and polonium.
